Reaction conditions: (1) Step 1: fructose (180 mg, 1 mmol) and Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H (10 mg) were added in DMSO (6 mL), 140 °C, 0.5 h, air atmosphere; Step 2: Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2, 1 mg), 140 °C, O2 (1 bar), 24 hThese results demonstrate the effectiveness of the binary catalyst system in promoting sequential reactions to achieve desirable DFF yields from fructose. However, applying this one-pot two-step method to glucose (1 mmol) as a starting material resulted in a low glucose conversion of 38% with an HMF selectivity of 84% (Step 1 in Figure S7). Although, the subsequent oxidation with Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) achieved a high selectivity of 95% for DFF formation, the overall DFF yield for this process remained at only 30%. Herein we report the synthesis of various of iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides (Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42) catalysts via a straightforward alkali-coprecipitation method. These catalyts exhibited notable highly efficiency as heterogeneous catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF. Among the catalysts investigated, Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) exhibited exceptional efficiency, achieving high HMF conversion (98 %) with high selectivity (>99 %) and turnover numbers (TONs) up to 379, representing 1–2 orders of magnitude improvement than previously reported non-noble catalysis systems. The Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) catalyst demonstrated sustained high selectivity after five usage cycles, highlighting its practical recyclability and stability. Comprehensive characterization of the catalysts and control experiments provided insights into active sites along with the structural, morphological, and surface properties. Furthermore, a convenient one-pot, two-step process utilizing Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H and Fe3BiMo12O42 in tandem successfully produced DFF from fructose with an impressive overall yield of 85%, showcasing potential for sustainable and eco-friendly biomass conversion. Graphical abstract This study presented an efficient method for converting 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) into 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) using iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxide (Fe3BiMo12O42) catalysts. A complete HMF conversion with remarkable selectivity (>95%) could be achieved, resulting in an impressive turnover number (TON) of up to 367. Moreover, the catalyst retained its selectivity and demonstrated good recyclability over five reaction cycles. . Comprehensive characterization of the catalysts and control experiments provided insights into active sites along with the structural, morphological, and surface properties. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Multicomponent metal oxides Aerobic oxidation 2,5-diformylfuran Biomass conversion Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction With the reduction of fossil resources and the deterioration of the global environment, there has been a growing interest in sourcing fuels and chemicals from sustainable biomass resources. [1–3] 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), an essential renewable platform chemical, acts as a bridge between the renewable biomass and petroleum industries, enabling the production of abundant fuel candidates and fine chemicals. [4–9] Among various HMF valorisation routes, selective oxidation of HMF can produce various industrially value-added furanic compounds (Fig. 1 ). Among these furanic compounds, 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF) has attracted much attention due to its wide applications including the synthesis of pharmaceutical intermediates [10], antifungal agents [11], nematicides [12], and act as monomer for preparation of many functional materials[13] and more. [14] In early studies, selective oxidation of HMF was achieved using stoichiometric oxidants such as NaClO [15], pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC), [16] and Pb(OAc)2 [17], etc. However, considering cost and sustainability, the utilization of molecular oxygen as oxidant has become more intriguing. As a result, numerous catalytic oxidation methods have emerged for converting HMF to DFF under aerobic conditions. For example, homogeneous catalytic systems such as Fe(NO3)3/TEMPO [18], CuCl/TEMPO [19], NaNO2/TEMPO [20], M(NO3)x/TEMPO [21], I2/TEMPO [22], Cu(NO3)2/VOSO4 [23], CuI/HBT [24] have demonstrated moderate to excellent yields (61–98%) for DFF production. However, these homogeneous catalytic systems still suffer from their poor recyclability, posing a challenge in terms of their practical application. In this context, numerous heterogeneous catalysts have been developed as potential alternatives to overcome the limitations of homogeneous systems. Noble metals such as Au [25,26], Pd [27], Ag [28,29], Pt [30], Rh [31], Ru [32–39], supported on various porous materials have demonstrated high activity in activating molecular oxygen for the oxidation of HMF to DFF. However, these catalysts still facing challenges due to their high cost and relatively low turnover numbers (TONs, <100), limiting their practical application on a large-scale process for HMF oxidation. Consequently, there has been a surge in exploring cost-effective catalytic systems based on metal free catalysts[40] and non-precious metals catalysts[41–63] for aerobic oxidation of HMF, addressing the need for more sustainable and affordable alternatives. Many transition metal-based oxides, such as single metal oxides (vanadium phosphate oxide [41–43], vanadium oxide [44], manganese oxide [45–48], γ-Fe2O3 49), supported molybdenum oxides[50] and encapsulated phosphomolybdic acid[51] V-Mo@CN [52], Fe3O4@C [53], Mo-HNC[54] have been successfully applied for the efficient oxidation of HMF. Recently, multicomponent metal oxides (e.g. MoO3-ZrO2 [55], CNP/FeVO4 [56], Co8Ce2Ox [57], α-CuV2O6 [58], Mn6Fe1Ox [59], Cs/MnOx [60], Co9Fe3BiMO12O51 [61], CeCu(OH)6Mo6O18 [62], Cs0.5H2.5Mo12O40 [63], (NH4)5H6PMo4V8O40 [64]) have emerged as more promising oxidation catalysts, exhibiting superior activity and recyclability compared to single metal oxides [65–69]. In recent years, several review articles have summarized advancements in the field of catalytic aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF, covering a variety of catalyst types, mechanisms, and reaction conditions [65,70–72]. However, current non-noble metal oxide catalysts still face challenges such as high catalyst loadings and relatively low TONs (<50). Thus, there is a persistent need to establish efficient and stable non-precious-metal based heterogeneous catalytic systems for HMF oxidation. Following our research interest in oxidation reactions using multicompetent metal oxide [61], herein, we synthesized various of iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxide catalysts (Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42) via an alkali-coprecipitation method and evaluated their efficacy in the aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF. The Fe3BiMo12O42 prepared at pH=1–2 exhibited exceptional efficiency, achieving 98% HMF conversion and high turnover numbers (TONs) up to 379. The high TONs surpassed all the previously reported methods using noble metals by 1–2 order of magnitudes. Notably, the high substrate to catalyst weight ratio (>2000 mmol/g) also represents over 20 times improvement over currently reported heterogeneous non-noble metal catalysts. The catalyst displayed a sustained selectivity (> 95%) and conversion (>70%) even after five usage cycles, indicating good stability and recyclability. Characterization techniques provided valuable insights into the catalyst's properties and active sites. Moreover, we demonstrated that fructose could be efficiently converted to DFF via a convenient one-pot method with Fe3BiMo12O42 or via a one-pot, two-step process employing Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H and Fe3BiMo12O42, achieving impressive yields of 69% and 85%, respectively. This highlights the potential of this Fe3BiMo12O42 for biomass conversion and cascade chemical synthesis, offering a promising route for sustainable chemical production. Results and discussion Synthesis and characterization of the iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides catalysts: Various of Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42 catalysts were prepared at different pH values (pH = 1–8) through a simple alkali-coprecipitation method modified from literature (For detailed synthesis procedures and their corresponding ICP analysis see SI) [73]. The morphological characteristics of the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–8) catalysts synthesized were characterized using SEM. As depicted in Figure S1, the Fe3BiMo12O42 catalysts manifested as micrometre-scale aggregated particles. Further BET analysis (Table S2 & Figure S2) revealed that the Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42 catalysts exhibited themselves as macroporous materials with low surface area (0.55–3.49 m2/g). The TEM images of the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) at different magnifications were depicted in Fig. 2 a-c. As shown in Fig. 2d, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping analysis of Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) demonstrated the uniform distribution of Fe, Bi, Mo elements within the catalyst. Moreover, the EDS also confirmed that the Fe content was much lower compared to the contents of Mo and Bi on the surface of the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) catalyst. This observation was in line with previous report [74], in which it proposed that during the synthesis of multicomponent bismuth molybdate catalysts, volatile oxides such as Bi2(MoO4)3 and MoO3 tended to locate on the catalyst's surface, while transition-metal molybdates were concentrated in the core of the catalyst. The XRD patterns of the multicomponent Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42 catalysts, prepared under different pH conditions were displayed in Fig. 3 . Each phase was identified by its characteristic peaks using the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS). It was determined that all the iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides catalysts consisted of three major mixed phases, namely Fe2(MoO4)3, Bi2(MoO4)3 and MoO3, which aligned well with previous study [75,76]. As presented in Table S1 and Table S2, the ICP-OES analysis confirmed that the molar ratio of Fe/Bi/Mo in all samples was consistent with the theoretical values of different iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides. The elemental composition and metal oxidation states of the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) catalyst were further assessed using high-resolution XPS. The peaks observed at binding energies of 710.2 eV (Fe 2p), 164.2 eV (Bi 4f), 232.2 eV (Mo 3d), and 530.2 eV (O1 s) in the full spectrum (Figure S3) confirmed the synthesized Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) composite primarily consisted of Fe, Bi, Mo, and O species. Additionally, prominent peaks at 236.2 eV (Mo 3d3/2), 233.0 eV (Mo 3d5/2), 726.0 eV (Fe 2p1/2), 712.2 eV (Fe 2p3/2), 165.0 eV (Bi 4f5/2), 159.7 eV (Bi 4f7/2) in Fig. 4 a-c indicated the presence of Mo6+, Fe3+ and Bi3+ in the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) [77–79]. The XPS analysis of O 1 s region allowed for the characterization of surface oxygen species. As demonstrated in Fig. 4d, three distinct types of surface oxygen species were discerned based on their binding energies, designated as Type-I, -II and -III in ascending order. The peaks observed at 530.3 eV, 531.4 eV, and 533.2 eV were attributed to lattice oxygen, surface chemisorbed oxygen or oxygen vacancies, and adsorbed water, respectively [60]. It was proposed that the Type-II oxygen could act as an indicator to reflect the oxygen mobility of the metal oxide catalysts for oxidation reactions [75,80,81]. Further detailed XPS analysis of O 1 s was conducted to investigate the intensity of different types of oxygen species in various iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxide catalysts (Table S3). HMF selective oxidation to DFF: The optimisation of selective oxidation of HMF commenced with an exploration of the influence of different reaction solvents using the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) catalyst (Fig. 5 a & Figure S4a). It was found that the choice of solvent had a pronounced influence on both the conversion of HMF and the selectivity towards DFF. Specifically, DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) exhibited excellent effectiveness in converting HMF to DFF, achieving 100% HMF conversion and a DFF yield of > 99 %. The excellent activity obtained using DMSO was consistent with previously reported oxidation system using multicomponent molybdenum- based catalysts [61,82]. In contrast, solvents such as DMF (dimethylformamide), toluene, MIBK (methyl isobutyl ketone), butyl acetate, ethylene glycol diacetate resulted in DFF yields between 1 and 11 %. Fig. 5b showed influence of reaction temperature on HMF conversion and DFF yield. The increasing of the reaction temperature from 120 °C to 140 °C led to a substantial improvement in both HMF conversion and DFF yield, with the DFF yield increasing from 9 % to >99 %. As shown in Fig. 5c, compared to reactions under air or N2 atmospheres, a notable increase in both conversion of HMF and the yield of DFF was observed when the reaction was conducted under an oxygen atmosphere. This observation underscored the pivotal role of oxygen as the terminal oxidant in our system. With the optimized reaction conditions identified (e.g., solvent - DMSO, temperature - 140 °C, and gas atmosphere - O2), a comparative analysis was conducted among various iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxide catalysts. As illustrated in Figure S4b, when employing a Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2, 10 mg) and a reaction time of 5 h under the optimized conditions, the variation in pH values during the synthesis of the Fe3BiMo12O42 catalyst resulted in negligible differences in catalytic performance. Subsequently, the effect of amount of catalyst on the HMF to DFF conversion was investigated. As shown in Figure S5, it was worth noting that the HMF oxidation reaction exhibited a very low conversion (12 %) in the absence of a catalyst, indicating that the conversion of DMF to DFF was primarily catalytic rather than occurring through autooxidation. Moreover, it was observed that under the conditions of 140 °C in an oxygen atmosphere for 5 h, utilizing a catalyst charge ranging between 5 and 10 mg, all led to similar excellent conversions of HMF (97−100 %) and yields of DFF (96−99 %). The marginal difference in conversions and yields between low and high catalyst loading demonstrated the excellent catalytic activity of the catalyst and suggested the potential to achieve similar yields with higher TONs with reduced catalyst loading by extending the reaction time (This proposition was further supported by the results detailed in subsequent section of the manuscript - gram-scales synthesis). To further assess the differences in catalytic performance among the variously prepared catalysts, the screening of catalysts was then conducted with shortened reaction time (3 h). As depicted in Fig. 6 a, the Fe3BiMo12O42 catalyst prepared at a low pH value (pH = 1–2) exhibited superior performance compared to those prepared at higher pH values (pH = 3–8). Among the Fe3BiMo12O42 catalyst synthesized at various pH values, the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) exhibited the highest Type II oxygen intensity (32.5 %), which was proposed to contribute to its enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity for the oxidation of HMF to DFF [75,80,81]. Fig. 6b presented the effect of metal component ratio on the oxidation of HMF using various iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxide catalysts, specifically Fe3BiMo8O30 (pH=1–2), Fe3BiMo10O36 (pH=1–2), Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2). Among the catalyst compositions tested, Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) with a molar ratio of Fe: Bi: Mo = 3: 1: 12 was identified as the optimal catalyst composition, exhibiting the highest HMF conversion and DFF yield. With Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) being identified as the most active catalyst in our study, further investigation was carried out to understand role of each metal oxide species within this catalyst. Therefore, the catalytic activity of various metal oxides (e.g., Fe2(MoO4)3, Bi2(MoO4)3, and MoO3) for HMF oxidation was investigated (for the synthesis procedures of Fe2(MoO4)3, Bi2(MoO4)3, please refer to the SI). As shown in Fig. 6c, these metal oxide components exhibited lower catalytic activity than that obtained with the multicomponent Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2). This was consistent with reported literature where molybdenum oxide, bismuth molybdates (e.g., Bi2Mo2O9, Bi2Mo3O12, Bi2MoO6), and iron doped-bismuth molybdates were reported as catalysts for oxidation reactions (e.g., alcohol oxidation and alkene oxidation) [83,84]. And their reactivity towards oxidation reactions could be further improved by forming multiphasic molybdate based catalysts (e.g., FexCo1-xMoO4, Fe3Co8BiMo12Ox). [74,85–89] It was proposed that in multicomponent metal oxides, one metal component typically served as the active site for oxidation, while the other constituents act as promoters to enhance the activity of the active component by modifying its redox or acid-base properties [55–58]. It was also reported that the electronic and structural modifications of bismuth molybdates could occur during the mixing and lead to synergy effects, potentially enhancing oxygen diffusion [86,87], reducing activation barriers [88], and boosting conductivity [89]. These enhancements might attribute to the outstanding activity of Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) catalyst in our reaction system. To further investigate the active metal species involved in our system, XPS analysis of the recycled Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) was carried out. As shown in Fig. 6d, new bands at 235.6 eV (Mo 3d3/2) and 232.5 eV (Mo 3d5/2) were observed, indicating the presence of Mo5+ in the recycled Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) catalyst. [90] No peaks corresponding to Mo4+ or Mo metal could be detected. [91] Conversely, the XPS spectra for Bi 4f and Fe 2p remained consistent to the fresh catalyst (Figure 4b&c and Figure 6e&f), suggesting no alteration in their oxidative states. Thus, it was proposed that the oxidation of HMF might be facilitated by Mo6+, which was then subsequently reduced to Mo5+ during the reaction. The Mo5+ was then oxidised to Mo6+ with O2 as the terminal oxidant. This observation aligns with previous literature, [61,62,92–95] where Mo6+ was proposed as the active sites for various oxidation reactions. As previously mentioned, the utilization of non-noble metal oxide catalysts still poses challenges, including high catalyst usage (<100 mmolsubstrate/gcatalyst) and low TONs (<50, see Table S5 for details). These limitations indicated the need for further advancements in catalyst design and optimization to enhance catalytic activity and achieve higher TONs to improve the overall efficiency of the catalytic process. In order to ascertain the potential of our catalyst to achieve high TONs under reduced catalyst quantities, a low catalyst loading of 4 mg was employed in the oxidation of HMF in gram scale (1 g, 8 mmol). Under the optimized conditions experimental depicted in Fig. 7 a, 98% conversion of HMF was attained, accompanied by a DFF yield of 98% within a prolonged reaction time of 24 h. It was noteworthy that the high conversion and selectivity were obtained under a high HMF mole to catalyst weight ratio of 2000 mmol/g (>20 times higher than all the reported aerobic catalytic processes utilizing non-noble metal catalysts, see Fig. 7b and Table S5 for more detailed comparation). The obtained turnover number (TON) based on the molar quantity of molybdenum was over 370, approximately one magnitude higher than all the previously reported literatures (Fig. 7b and see Table S5 for more detailed comparison). We next investigated the recyclability of the Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) under gram-scale reaction conditions over multiple cycles. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was collected by centrifugation and then thoroughly washed with water and ethanol. Following this, the catalyst was dried for 4 h at 80 °C under vacuum conditions before being reused for the subsequent cycle under the same reaction conditions. As depicted in Fig. 7c, the catalyst's good recyclability was demonstrated, albeit slightly decrease was observed for the yield of DFF. Although the DFF yield was reduced to 72% on the fifth cycle, high selectivity (>99%) and an impressive TON over 250 was still obtained. To understand the decline in catalytic activity of Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2), analysis of the recycled catalyst was conducted by SEM, TEM, EDS, ICP, and XRD (detailed result of these characterization see Table S1 and Figure S8–10). The XRD analysis revealed noticeable changes in the intensity patterns of Fe₂(MoO₄)₃, Bi₂(MoO₄)₃, and MoO₃ after the reaction. Specifically, a relative decrease in the intensities of Fe₂(MoO₄)₃ and MoO₃ was observed compared to Bi₂(MoO₄)₃. Based on EDS and ICP analysis, negligible changes in the metal composition of the catalyst were observed after the reaction, indicating that metal leaching was not significant. SEM analysis revealed that the recycled catalysts formed smaller particles, potentially due to fragmentation during the reaction process. Therefore, we propose that the observed reduction in catalytic activity is likely due to structural or phase changes in the Fe₂(MoO₄)₃ and MoO₃ components rather than changes in the overall metal composition. The exceptional catalytic activity exhibited by Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) in the oxidation of HMF to DFF has provided strong motivation for us to explore a route for the production of DFF from a more economically viable starting materials like fructose and glucose. Initially, fructose (1 mmol) served as starting material in this one-pot one-step method using Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2, 1 mg) as catalyst. As shown in Figure S6a, a good yield of 69% DFF could be obtained within 24 h. To further enhance the yield of DFF, we investigated the consecutive synthesis of DFF from fructose using a binary heterogeneous catalyst system. The catalyst system consisted of two components: a recoverable acid catalyst known as Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H [96], and Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2). This combination of catalysts was chosen to facilitate the one-pot two-step process (Fig. 8 ). In Step 1, Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H was employed as catalyst for the dehydration of fructose to HMF. Remarkably, within a mere 0.5 hours under atmospheric air conditions, a substantial HMF yield of 90% was achieved. Subsequently, the Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H catalyst was separated using a magnet, and Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2, 1 mg) was introduced to the solution. This marked the initiation of Step 2, which involved the oxidation of HMF and subsequent formation of DFF. Over a reaction time of 24 h under atmospheric O2 conditions, an impressive DFF selectivity of 95% was achieved, leading to an overall yield of 85% (for kinetic analysis see Figure S6b for more details). Conclusions This study presented the synthesis of a series of iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides (Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42) using a straightforward alkali-coprecipitation method. Among the investigated catalysts, Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) exhibited exceptional efficiency for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF, resulting in a 98% conversion of the HMF and achieving a remarkable selectivity of ≥99% with TONs of up to 379. This TON value represented an order of magnitude improvement in catalytic activity compared to previously reported methods. Additionally, this catalyst's high substrate-to-catalyst weight ratio (>2000 mmol/g) signifies a 20-fold improvement over current heterogeneous non-noble metal systems. The Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH=1–2) catalyst showed sustained excellent selectivity performance with good recyclability and stability for five usage cycles. The physical and chemical properties of these catalysts were carefully investigated using modern characterization techniques, which provided valuable insights into the catalyst's structural, morphological, surface properties and active sites. Furthermore, a convenient one-pot two-step process utilizing Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H and Fe3BiMo12O42 catalysts in a tandem heterogeneous manner was successfully employed to produce DFF from fructose with an impressive overall DFF yield of > 85%. Our catalytic system represented a significant advancement in the selective oxidation of HMF, contributing to advancements in biomass valorisation and sustainable chemical transformations, promoting greener and more efficient approaches in biomass conversion and chemical synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Herein we report the synthesis of various of iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides (Fe3BiMo8–12O30–42) catalysts via a straightforward alkali-coprecipitation method. These catalyts exhibited notable highly efficiency as heterogeneous catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to DFF. Among the catalysts investigated, Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) exhibited exceptional efficiency, achieving high HMF conversion (98 %) with high selectivity (>99 %) and turnover numbers (TONs) up to 379, representing 1–2 orders of magnitude improvement than previously reported non-noble catalysis systems. The Fe3BiMo12O42 (pH = 1–2) catalyst demonstrated sustained high selectivity after five usage cycles, highlighting its practical recyclability and stability. Comprehensive characterization of the catalysts and control experiments provided insights into active sites along with the structural, morphological, and surface properties. Furthermore, a convenient one-pot, two-step process utilizing Fe3O4@SiO2-SO3H and Fe3BiMo12O42 in tandem successfully produced DFF from fructose with an impressive overall yield of 85%, showcasing potential for sustainable and eco-friendly biomass conversion.

coredata.dc:title: High-efficiency synthesis of 2,5-diformylfuran from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural using iron-bismuth-molybdenum oxides
